questions.text: A 30 year old female who was diagnosed with SLE - Lupus nephritis 4 years back, but lost to follow up, now presented with acute onset breathlessness to the emergency department. On examination, she had a pulse rate of 128/min, irregular. Auscultation revealed mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. There were bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Serum creatinine was 4mg/dl. ECG is shown below. What would be the oral anticoagulant of choice for her?
questions.solution: The patient in question has presented with an acute pulmonary edema, probably as a result of decompensated Atrial Fibrillation. Presence of MDM also suggests there might be an underlying mitral stenosis. So, definitely the patient requires anticoagulation in addition to management of acute pulmonary edema. Since she is having an underlying Chronic Kidney Disease, choice of anticoagulation has to be prudent. Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban and apixaban has renal excretion and hence not preferred in severe renal insufficiency. So, warfarin is preferred as its route of excretion is via the liver.

questions.text: The following murmur pattern is seen in :
questions.solution:
• Ejection systolic/Midsystolic murmur
  • Crescendo-decrescendo configuration
  • Begins after S1 and ends before S2
  • Seen in Aortic stenosis, Pulmonic stenosis, HOCM, flow murmurs

questions.text: Continuous murmurs may be seen in ?
questions.solution: The below is the table in Harrison mentioning all the causes of continuous murmurs.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with complaints of loose stools , abdominal pain and weight loss of 3 months duration. He also complaints of vague joint pains. Initial lab tests were unyielding. He was subjected to endoscopy and small intestinal biopsy. The pathologist reports presence of PAS positive macrophages in the biopsy specimen. What is the specific treatment to be initiated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of Whipple’s disease is prolonged use of antibiotics. The current regimen of choice is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (160/800 mg) twice a day for 1 year. If TMP-SMX is not tolerated, chloramphenicol is an appropriate second choice.
Ref: Harrison 20th edition page 2256

choices.text: Removal of clot from cerebral circulation
Removal of clot from coronary circulation

questions.text: The following device is used in ?
questions.solution: The device shown is the Amplatzer septal occluder used in the closure of ASD

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign demonstrated in the image below ?
questions.solution:
PRONATOR DRIFT (Barre's sign) - Subtle sign of UMN lesion Patient is asked to hold both the upper limbs outstretched, symmetrically in front with the palms facing upwards (supinated) and then asked to close both eyes tightly. Watch for the position of weak limb. The weak limb pronates and drifts down.

Reason - In corticospinal tract lesion, the selectively weakened muscles are shoulder abductors, external rotators, supinators and elbow extensors. So, the action of these weak muscles are overcome by the antagonists causing pronation, elbow flexion and downward drift.

choices.text: Age group affected is 2nd and 3rd decade
Restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing

questions.text: False statement regarding cryptogenic organizing pneumonia ?
questions.solution:
Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Age group – 6th and 7th decade

Clinical presentation – Subacute flu like illness with cough, dyspnea, fever and fatigue
Examination – Inspiratory crepitations

Pulmonary function test – Restrictive pattern
Imaging – Patchy subpleural consolidative opacities often associated with ground glass opacities
Treatment – Corticosteroids. Alternative agents are cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, rituximab

questions.text: A 40 year old diabetic patient presented with headache and fever of 2 months duration. Possibility of chronic meningitis was kept in the ward rounds and CSF study was advised. The resident who performed the lumbar puncture noticed the following sometime after collecting the CSF sample in test tube. What is the likely etiological agent?
questions.solution: Cobweb coagulum is a feature of tuberculous meningitis due to high content of protein in the CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not in the acute therapy of aortic dissection?
questions.solution:
Medical therapy should be initiated as soon as the diagnosis of aortic dissection is considered. The patient should be admitted to an intensive care unit for hemodynamic monitoring. Unless hypotension is present, therapy should be aimed at reducing cardiac contractility and systemic arterial pressure, and thus shear stress. For acute dissection, unless contraindicated, β-adrenergic blockers should be administered parenterally, using intravenous propranolol, metoprolol, or the short-acting esmolol to achieve a heart rate of ~60 beats/min. This should be accompanied by sodium nitroprusside infusion to lower systolic blood pressure to ≤120 mmHg. Labetalol , a drug with both β- and α-adrenergic blocking properties, also may be used as a parenteral agent in acute therapy for dissection.

The calcium channel antagonists verapamil and diltiazem may be used intravenously if nitroprusside or β-adrenergic blockers cannot be employed. The addition of a parenteral ACE inhibitor such as enalaprilat to a β-adrenergic blocker also may be considered. Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and may propagate the dissection.

Reference: Harrison 20th edition page 1921

questions.text: Which of the following neurologic disease can have the peripheral smear finding?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis. Neurological conditions that have acanthocytes in peripheral smear are :

  • Neuroacanthocytosis
  • Abetalipoproteinemia (Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome)

questions.text: Most common mutation found in MODY is :
questions.solution: Most common type of MODY is MODY-3

questions.text: Not a component of Crow-Fukase syndrome?
questions.solution:
POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, M-protein, and skin changes; also known as Crow-Fukase syndrome) patients usually present with a progressive sensorimotor polyneuropathy, diabetes mellitus (50%), primary gonadal failure (70%), and a plasma cell dyscrasia with sclerotic bony lesions. Associated findings can be hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and hyperpigmentation. Patients often present in the fifth to sixth decade of life and have a median survival after diagnosis of <3 years
Reference : Harrison 20th edition page 2759

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presents with the following skin changes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dyskeratosis congenita is the classic telomere disease, a mainly pediatric syndrome diagnosed in the first two decades of life. Affected children have at least two features of the mucocutaneous triad of ungual dystrophy, reticular skin pigmentation, and oral leukoplakia.
Reference : Harrison 20th edition page 3468

questions.text: Which of the following is not a late manifestation of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Coomb’s negative hemolytic anaemia is an early manifestation of congenital syphilis.

Syphilis during pregnancy has a transmission rate approaching 100%. Early signs appear during first two years of life. Late signs appear gradually during first two decades. Early manifestations result from transplacental spirochetemia and are analogous to secondary stage of acquired syphilis.

Late manifestations include

  • Frontal bossing
  • Olympian brow
  • Higoumenakis sign
  • Saber shin
  • Scaphoid scapula
  • Hutchinson teeth
  • Abnormal enamel
  • Mulberry molar

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Barrter syndrome?
questions.solution:
Barrter's syndrome

  • Result from mutation affecting any of the five ion transport proteins in the thick ascending limb of loop of henle.
  • Most often presents in the neonatal period or early childhood with polyuria, polydipsia, salt craving and growth retardation
  • Blood pressure is normal or low
  • Metabolic abnormalities mimics chronic ingestion of loop diuretic
  • Metabolic abnormalities include hypokalemia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, decreased urinary concentrating and diluting ability, hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis, mild hypomagnesemia and increased urinary prostaglandin secretion

questions.text: Not true regarding Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is an aggressive and potentially fatal syndrome which results from inappropriate activation of lymphocytes and macrophages.

Criteria for diagnosis of HLH – Five out of 8 criteria needs to be fulfilled

  1. Fever
  2. Splenomegaly
  3. Cytopenias in atleast 2 cell lines
  4. Hypertriglyceridemia
  5. Hemophagocytosis
  6. Low or absent activity of natural killer cells
  7. Serum ferritin > 500mcg/l
  8. Soluble IL-2 receptor (CD25) > 2400 U/ml

choices.text: PTH receptors fail to respond to PTH
Serum calcium levels are high due to underlying bone pathology

questions.text: In pseudohypoparathyroidism:
questions.solution:
PSEUDOHYPOPARATHYROIDISM

  • Characterised by signs and symptoms of hypocalcemia in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects.
  • Hypocalcemia is due to a deficient response to PTH, which is probably restricted to the proximal renal tubules.
  • Hyperplasia of the parathyroids,a response to hormone resistant hypocalcemia,causes elevation of PTH levels.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP) is classified into four types.

  • PHP type Ia
  • PHP type Ib
  • Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
  • PHP type II

The basis of this classification is :

  • Signs of ineffective PTH action (low calcium and high phosphate).
  • Low or normal urinary cAMP response to exogenous PTH.
  • Presence or absence of Alhright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO).
  • Assays to measure the concentration of the Gsα subunit of the adenylate cyclase enzyme.

choices.text: The enzyme defect enhances the reutilization of purine bases

questions.text: A 8 year old boy subnormal intelligence was brought to the OPD with history of self mutilation. Choose the false statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The Salvage pathway ensures recycling/reutilisation of purines formed by degradation of nucleotides. In Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, this pathway is defective.

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome

  • X-linked disorder of purine metabolism.
  • There is deficiency of Hypoxanthine Guanine Phosphoribosyl Transferase (HGPRTase).
  • Thus the salvage pathway is decreased resulting in accumulation of PRPP and decreased level of inhibitory purine nucleotides.
  • Characterised by self mutilation, mental retardation, excessive uric acid and nephrolithiasis.
  • Gout develops in later life.
  • The neurological manifestations is because of the fact that the brain is dependent on the salvage pathway for the requirements of IMP and GMP.

questions.text: Porphyria cutanea tarda is caused by deficiency of :
questions.solution:
Porphyria Cutanea Tarda

  • Most common type of porphyria.
  • Can either be sporadic (type 1- 80%) or familial.
  • There is hepatic and bone marrow  involvement, though it is classified as a hepatic porphyria
  • Enzyme deficient is uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
  • Blistering skin lesions that appear most commonly on the back of hands are the major clinical feature. These rupture and crust over leaving areas of atrophy and scarring.
  • Higher incidence of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (most common cause of death in PCT).

questions.text: Byssinosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by :
questions.solution:
BYSSINOSIS

  • Asthma like syndrome seen in workers exposed to cotton dust (but also to flax, hemp or jute dust).
  • Characterized clinically as occasional (early-stage) and then regular (late-stage) chest tightness toward the end of the first day of the workweek ('Monday chest tightness').
  • Exposed workers may show a significant drop in FEV1 over the course of a Monday work shift.
  • After > 10 years of exposure, workers with recurrent symptoms are more likely to have an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function testing.

questions.text: Predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in :
questions.solution:
Dubin-Johnson Syndrome

  • Rare and relatively benign disorder characterised by low-grade predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Defect in the ATP dependent canalicular membrane transporter MRP-2 protein.
  • Cardinal feature is the accumulation in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes of dark, coarsely granular pigment. As a result, the liver may be grossly black in appearance.

Let’s have a look at the caused grouped under unconjugated and conjugated hyperbilirubinemias.

questions.text: The following are features of hypersensitivity pneumonitis except :
questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) also referred to as extrinsic allergic alveolitis,is a pulmonary disease that occurs due to inhalational exposure to a variety of antigens leading to an inflammatory response of the alveoli and small airways.

Diagnosis of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis

  • All forms of the disease may be associated with elevations in erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, rheumatoid factor, lactate dehydrogenase, or serum immunoglobulins.
  • Following acute exposure to an antigen, neutrophilia and lymphopenia are frequently present.
  • Eosinophilia is NOT a feature.
  • Examination for serum precipitins against suspected antigens, is an important part of the diagnostic workup and should be performed on any patient with interstitial lung disease, especially if a suggestive exposure history is elicited.
  • The occurrence of precipitins indicates sufficient exposure to the causative agent for generation of an immunologic response and is one of the major diagnostic criteria; however, the diagnosis of HP is not established solely by the presence of precipitins, as they are found in sera of many individuals exposed to appropriate antigens who demonstrate no other evidence of HP.
  • Chest x-ray shows no specific or distinctive changes in HP. It can be normal even in symptomatic patients.
  • In cases of acute HP, the chest X-ray typically shows ill-defined patchy airspace shadowing which may be confused with pneumonia. HRCT is more likely to show bilateral ground glass shadowing and areas of consolidation superimposed on small centrilobar nodular opacities with an upper and middle lobe predominance.
  • In the chronic phase, the chest x-ray usually shows a diffuse reticulonodular infiltrate.
  • Honeycombing may eventually develop as the condition progresses.

choices.text: Nasal Epithelial electrical potential difference measurements can be used for diagnosis
CFTR gene is located on chromosome 6

questions.text: The following are true of cystic fibrosis except :
questions.solution:
The primary defect in cystic fibrosis results from abnormal function of an epithelial chloride channel protein encoded by the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q.

Regarding other options :
Option A:  Sweat test is highly specific for Cystic fibrosis. Malfunction of CFTR leads to diminished chloride uptake from sweat duct lumen and thus sweat emerges on the skin with markedly elevated levels of chloride.

Option B: In vivo measurement of ion transport across the nasal airways can serve as specific test for cystic fibrosis. Elevated transepithelial charge separation across airway epithelial tissue is highly specific.

Option C: Organisms routinely cultured from sputum of cystic fibrosis patients are Staph aureus, H.influenzae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A pleural fluid NT-pro BNP > 1500 pg/ml is diagnostic of effusion due to :
questions.solution:
The most common cause of pleural effusion is left ventricular failure. A pleural fluid N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) >1500 pg/mL is virtually diagnostic that the effusion is secondary to congestive heart failure.

Keep in mind a similar numerical from Harrison. The diagnosis of tuberculous pleural effusion can be demonstrated by an elevation of adenosine deaminase >40 IU/L or interferon gamma >140 pg/mL in pleural fluid.

questions.text: A 48 year old female diagnosed with SLE at 20 years of age and on irregular medications, now presents with pain and deformity of both hands. Examination showed that the deformity shown in figure below is manually reversible on applying force. What is the likely reason for the deformity?
questions.solution:
In Jaccoud’s arthropathy, the deformities are reducible and result mainly from soft-tissue abnormalities, such as laxity of ligaments, fibrosis of the capsule, and muscular imbalance, rather than from destruction of the bone of joints, as occurs in rheumatoid arthritis (in which deformity is not reducible)

Jaccoud's arthropathy was initially described in relation to rheumatic fever, but now more cases are seen in association with SLE, other connective tissue diseases and neoplasias

choices.text: Millet seed lesions on chest X-ray

questions.text: The following are features of cryptic military tuberculosis except :
questions.solution:
Miliary or disseminated TB is due to hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli.Cryptic military tuberculosis is an unusual presentation of military TB seen in elderly. Let’s have a look at the features:

  • Age over 60 years.
  • Intermittent low grade pyrexia of unknown origin.
  • Unexplained weight loss,general debility.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly in 25-50% of cases.
  • NORMAL CHEST X-RAY.
  • Blood dyscrasias- leukaemoid reaction, pancytopenia.
  • Negative tuberculin skin test.
  • Confirmation by biopsy of liver or bone marrow.

questions.text: Lofgren syndrome is a type of :
questions.solution: Lofgren's syndrome is a form of Sarcoidosis seen in young adults. It is an acute illness characterised by erythema nodosum,peripheral arthropathy, uveitis, bilateral hilar adenopathy,lethargy and occasionally fever.

questions.text: Chaga's disease can cause :
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal manifestations of Chaga's disease

  • Chronic Chaga’s disease of the GI tract is also known as 'megadisease' as the esophagus and colon may exhibit varying degrees of dilation.
  • On microscopic examination, focal inflammatory lesions with lymphocytic infiltration are seen, and the number of neurons in the myenteric plexus may be markedly reduced.
  • Patients with megaesophagus suffer from dysphagia,odynophagia? chest pain,and regurgitation.
  • Aspiration can occur (especially during sleep) in patients with severe esophageal dysfunction,and repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonitis are common.

questions.text: Erythrasma is caused by :
questions.solution:
ERYTHRASMA

  • Cutaneous infection producing reddish brown,macular,scaly,pruritic intertriginous patches.
  • Etiological agent - Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  • Wood’s lamp examination shows characteristic 'coral red fluorescence'.
  • Treatment – Responds to topical erythromycin, clarithromycin, clindamycin or fusidic acid, although more severe infections may require oral macrolide therapy.

questions.text: The sign of groove is seen in :
questions.solution:
Lymphogranuloma venereum

  • Etiological agents : Chlamydia serovars L1, L2 and L3.
  • Sexually transmitted. Peak incidence is in 2nd and 3rd decade of life.
  • Three stages of the disease are recognized:
    1. Primary stage
    2. Inguinal syndrome
    3. Genito-anorectal syndrome
  • Primary stage begins as a small painless papule that tends to ulcerate at the site of inoculation and heals without scarring.
  • The most common presenting picture in heterosexual men and women is inguinal syndrome, which is characterised by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy beginning 2-6 weeks after presumed exposure.
  • Extensive enlargement of chains of inguinal nodes above and below the inguinal ligament produces the 'sign of groove' – whereby the nodes are separated by inguinal ligament.
  • Genito-anorectal syndrome is characterised by hyperplastic and ulcerative changes on the genitilia frequently associated with anorectal change. Manifestations are more frequent in women with the typical manifestation being ‘esthiomene’ (ulcaeration and elephantiasis of the vulval and perianal skin).

questions.text: Primary chancre of syphilis generally heals within :
questions.solution:
PRIMARY SYPHILIS

  • Typical lesion is primary chancre.
  • Median incubation period – 21 days
  • Sites of primary chancre
    • Penis in heterosexual men.
    • Anal canal or rectum in homosexual men
    • Cervix and labia in women
  • Begins as single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated with a characteristic cartillagenous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.
  • Regional (usually inguinal) lymphadenopathy accomapanies the primary syphilitic lesion. The nodes are firm, non-suppurative and painless.
  • The chancre generally heals within 4-6 weeks, but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

questions.text: Osborn waves on ECG occur in :
questions.solution:
ECG changes in hypothermia

  • Most characteristic ECG sign of hypothermia is the ‘J’ or Junctional wave.
  • J wave is a hump like deflection which occurs at the junction of the distal limb of QRS complex with the ST segment .
  • The amplitude of this deflection is proportional to the degree of hypothermia.
  • Distinctive convex elevation of the J point in hypothermia is known as Osborn wave.


      • Other ECG changes associated with hypothermia are :

      • Sinus bradycardia
      • First and second degree AV block
      • Ectopic rhythms
      • Prolongation of QRS complex duration
      • Prolongation of QT interval

choices.text: Jugular venous distension with prominent x descent

questions.text: All of the following constitute Beck's triad except :
questions.solution:
Beck’s triad is a feature of cardiac tamponade.Pericardial knock is not a component of the triad.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

  • Results from fluid accumulation in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles.
  • Quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 ml when the fluid accumulates rapidly to as much as >2000 ml in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.
  • Causes
    • Most common causes of are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease.
    • May also result from bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operations, trauma and treatment of patients with acute pericarditis with anticoagulants.
  • Three principal features seen in severe cardiac tamponade are together known as
    • Beck’s triad
    • Hypotension.
    • Soft or absent heart sounds.
    • Jugular venous distension with a prominent x descent but an absent y descent
  • ECG findings
    • Reduced voltage and electrical alternans.
    • Reduced voltage is non-specific and can be caused by a variety of other conditions (eg:emphysema,infiltrative myocardial disease,pneumothorax)
    • Electrical alternans means beat to beat variation in both the amplitude and axis of the QRS complex.
    • It occurs due to large amplitude rhythmic swinging of the heart within the pericardial sac, in presence of a large pericardial effusion.
    • A minimum of 200 ml of fluid is required for manifestation of electrical alternans.
    • Electrical alternans is specific and pathognomonic,but relatively insensitive.

PERICARDIAL KNOCK

  • Also known as “third heart sound of constrictive pericarditis”.
  • Early diastolic sound best heard at the left sternal border or the cardiac apex.
  • Corresponds to the early,abrupt cessation of ventricular filling by the thick,adherent and fibrosed pericardium.
  • Occurs slightly earlier and has higher frequency than a typical third heart sound.

questions.text: The following drugs are used in the treatment of acute severe asthma except:
questions.solution:
Treatment of Acute Severe Asthma

  • High concentration of oxygen via face mask to achieve oxygen saturation of >90%.
  • Mainstay of treatment are high doses of SABA given either by nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler with a spacer.
  • ln severely ill patients with impending respiratory failure, v beta2-agonists may be given.
  • A nebulized anticholinergic may be added if there is not a satisfactory response to beta 2-agonists alone, as there are additive effects.
  • In patients who are refractory to inhaled therapies, a slow infusion of aminophylline may be effective,but it is important to monitor blood levels? especially if patients have already been treated with oral theophylline.
  • Magnesium sulfate given intravenously or by nebulizer is effective when added to inhaled beta 2-agonists,and is relatively well tolerated but is not routinely recommended.
  • Prophylactic intubation may be indicated for impending respiratory failure,when the PC02 is normal or rises.
  • For patients with respiratory failure,it is necessary to intubate and institute ventilation. These patients may benefit from an anesthetic such as halothane if they have not responded to conventional bronchodilators.
  • Sedatives should never be given because they may depress ventilation.
  • Antibiotics should not be used routinely unless there are signs of pneumonia.

OMALIZUMAB

  • Blocking antibody that neutralizes circulating IgE without binding to cell-bound IgE and,thus, inhibits IgE-mediated reactions.
  • Reduce the number of exacerbations in patients with severe asthma and may improve asthma control. However, it is not useful in treatment of acute severe asthma.
  • Very expensive and is only suitable for highly selected patients who are not controlled on maximal doses of inhaler therapy and have a circulating IgE within a specified range.
  • Usually given as a subcutaneous injection every 2-4 weeks.

questions.text: Ventilator associated pneumonia caused by MRSA is treated with :
questions.solution:
Specific treatment of MDR-VRSA

  • VAP caused by MRSA is associated with a 40% clinical failure rate when treated with standard-dose vancomycin.
  • One proposed solution is the use of high-dose individualized treatment? although the risk of renal toxicity increases with this strategy.
  • Linezolid appears to be 15% more efficacious than even adjusted-dose vancomycin and is clearly preferred in patients with renal insufficiency and those infected with high-MIC isolates of MRSA.

questions.text: Hyperekplexia occurs due to mutations in :
questions.solution: Hyperekplexia(startle syndrome) is characterised by marked muscular hypertonia and severe jerks induced by sound or tactile stimuli. Classic hyperekplexia is caused by genetic mutations in a number of different genes, all of which play an important role in glycine neurotransmission.

choices.text: Upper motor neurons of brain stem
Lower motor neurons of brain stem
Lower motor neurons of spinal cord
Upper motor neurons of spinal cord

questions.text: In spinal muscular atrophy which set of neurons is affected?
questions.solution:
Spinal Muscular Atrophy

  • Autosomal recessive disease.
  • Lower motor neurons of spinal cord are affected.
  • Caused by mutations in the SMN 1gene, encoding the SMN protein essential for survival of anterior motor horn cells.

There are three clinical types :

  • Type 1 disease (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease)
    • profound hypotonia, flaccid weakness and global areflexia.
    • respiratory weakness, poor swallowing and tongue fasciculations.
    • usually never learn to sit.
    • aspiration pneumonia is an important cause of mortality and morbidity.
  • Type 2 disease (Dubowitz disease)
  • Type 3 disease (Kugelberg-Welander disease)

questions.text: The most common site of hypertensive intracranial bleed is :
questions.solution:
Hypertensive Intracerebral haemorrhage

  • It is the most common type of intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Results from spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain.
  • Small arteries in the following areas seem most prone to hypertension-induced vascular injury :
    • Putamen (most common site)
    • Globus pallidus
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellar hemisphere
    • Pons

choices.text: Serum antibody to alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen

questions.text: Which of the following is usually present in neuromyelitis optica ?
questions.solution:
NEUROMYELITIS OPTICA

  • Immune mediated demyelinating disorder.
  • Characterised by severe myelopathy that is typically longitudinally extensive (means that the lesion spans three or more vertebral segments).
  • Associated with optic neuritis that is often bilateral and may precede or follow myelitis by weeks or months and also by brainstem and in some cases hypothalamic involvement.
  • Recurrent myelitis without optic nerve involvement can also occur.
  • CSF studies reveal a variable mononuclear pleocytosis of upto several hundred cells per microliter. UNLIKE MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, CSF OLIGOCLONAL BANDS ARE ABSENT.
  • Diagnostic serum autoantibodies against the water channel protein aquaporin-4 are present in 60-70% of patients .
  • May be associated with SLE and antiphospholipid antibodies as well as with other systemic autoimmune diseases.
  • Rare cases are of paraneoplastic origin.
  • Treatment is with glucocorticoids and for refractory cases plasma exchange.
  • Preliminary studies suggest that treatment with azathioprine? mycophenylate, or anti-CD20 (anti-B cell) monoclonal antibody may protect against subsequent relapses; treatment for 5 years or longer is generally recommended.

questions.text: The only approved treatment for primary biliary cirrhosis is ?
questions.solution:
Though a variety of therapies have been proposed, UDCA is the only approved treatment that has some degree of efficacy by slowing the rate of progression of the disease.

PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS

  • Strong female preponderance.
  • Median age at diagnosis is 50 years.
  • Cause is unknown.
  • Pathology
    • Portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium sized bile ducts.
    • Earliest lesion is “chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis”
  • Clinical features
    • Most patients are asymptomatic.
    • Severe fatigue.
    • Debilitating pruritus. Pruritus that presents prior to the development of jaundice indicates severe disease and poor prognosis.
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly,Splenomegaly,Ascites and Edema.
    • Hyperpigmentation, Xanthelasma, Xanthomata (due to altered cholesterol metabolism)
    • Bone pain resulting from osteopenia or osteoporosis.
  • Lab findings
    • Cholestatic pattern with elevated GGT and ALP.
    • Immunoglobulins,particularly IgM are typically increased.
    • Hyperbilirubinemia (once cirrhosis has developed).
    • Thrombocytopenia,Leukopenia and Anaemia (in patients with portal hypertension and hypersplenism).
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 90% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Upto 10% of patients with characteristic PBC have features of Autoimmune hepatitis as well and are defined as having “overlap” syndrome.
  • TREATMENT : UDCA is the only approved treatment.
    • Improves both biochemical and histological features of the disease.
    • Slows the rate of progression of PBC, but it does not reverse or cure the disease.

questions.text: The best therapy for hepatorenal syndrome is :
questions.solution:
HEPATORENAL SYNDROME (HRS)

  • Form of functional renal failure without renal pathology in patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure.
  • HRS is classified into two types based on clinical characteristics and prognosis.
  • Type 1 HRS
    • Characterized by a rapidly progressive form of renal dysfunction.
    • Serum creatinine level doubles to a value higher than 2.5 mg/dL in a period of 2 weeks or less.
  • Type 2 HRS
    • More slowly progressive and has better outcome than type 1 HRS
    • Serum creatinine levels are less than 2.5 mg/dl.
  • TREATMENT OF HRS
    • In the past,dopamine or prostaglandin analogues were used as renal vasodilating medications.
    • Currently,patients are treated with midodrine,an α-agonist,along with octreotide and intravenous albumin.
    • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting. In patients with either type 1 or type 2 HRS, the prognosis is poor unless transplant can be achieved within a short period of time.

questions.text: Identify the stage of pericarditis from the ECG ?
questions.solution:
Stage I: ST elevation in all leads and PR depression

Stage II: pseudonormalisation

Stage III: inverted T-waves

Stage IV: normalisation

questions.text: Apnea test is done for the diagnosis of :
questions.solution:
Brain death is a state of irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means. It is the only type of brain damage recognized as equivalent to death.

APNEA TEST

  • Difficult clinical test, potentially harmful and lengthy. However, when an appropriate oxygen diffusion procedure is used, this technique is safe.
  • Brain death is diagnosed when no respiratory movements occur when the patient is disconnected from the ventilator for long enough to ensure that the carbon dioxide concentration in the blood rises above the threshold for stimulating respiration.
  • CO2 tension increases ~0.3-0.4 kPa/min (2-3 mmHg/min) during apnea.
  • Arterial PCO2,should be at least >6.6-8.0 kPa (50-60 mmHg) for the test to be valid.
  • Apnea is confirmed if no respiratory effort has been observed in the presence of a sufficiently elevated PCO2.
  • Other techniques, including the administration of CO2 to accelerate the test,are used in special circumstances.
  • The apnea test is usually stopped if there is serious cardiovascular instability.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a treatment option for multiple recurrent clostridium difficile infection ?
questions.solution:
Recurrent Clostridium difficile infection

  • Approximately 15-30 % of successfully treated patients experience recurrence of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) either as relapses caused by the original organism or as reinfections following treatment.
  • There is no standard treatment for multiple recurrence but long or repeated metronidazole courses should be avoided because of potential neurotoxicity.
  • Most practical approach to treatment of patients with multiple recurrences is Vancomycin in tapering doses or with pulse dosing every other day for 2-8 weeks.
  • Other approaches include the administration of vancomycin followed by the yeast Saccharomyces boulardii; the administration of vancomycin followed by a fecal microbiota transplant given via nasoduodenal tube,colonoscope,or enema; and the intentional colonization of the patient with a nontoxigenic  strain of  difficile.
    ther antibiotic strategies include :
    (1) sequential treatment with vancomycin (125 mg four times daily for 10-14days) followed by rifaximin (400 mg twice daily for 14 days) and
    (2) treatment with nitazoxanide (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).
  • IV immunoglobulin,which has also been used with variable success? presumably provides antibodies to C.difficile toxins.

questions.text: The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is :
questions.solution:
Pulmonary manifestations of SLE

  • Most common pulmonary manifestation is pleuritis with or without pleural effusion.
  • Pulmonary infiltrates also occur as a manifestation of active SLE and are difficult to distinguish from infection on imaging studies.
  • Life-threatening pulmonary manifestations include interstitial inflammation leading to fibrosis,shrinking lung syndrome,and intraalveolar hemorrhage; all of these probably require early aggressive immunosuppressive therapy as well as supportive care.

questions.text: The most common form of acute kidney injury is due to :
questions.solution:
The causes of acute kidney injury can be classified into three major categories:

  • Pre-renal azotemia
  • Intrinsic renal parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction


Among these causes, pre-renal azotemia is the most common form of AKI.

questions.text: The Cockroft-Gault equation is used for the estimation of :
questions.solution:
In most clinical circumstances,direct GFR measurement is not feasible,and the plasma creatinine level is used as a surrogate to estimate GFR.

Two formulas are widely used to estimate kidney function from plasma creatinine:
i)Cockroft-Gault formula
ii)Four variable MDRD (Modification of Diet in Renal Disease)



Where PCr is the plasma creatinine.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of constipation of IBS?
questions.solution:
Lubiprostone

  • Bicyclic fatty acid that stimulates chloride channels in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Chloride secretion induces passive movement of sodium and water into the bowel lumen and improves bowel function.
  • Found to be effective in the treatment of patients with constipation predominant Irritable bowel syndrome

questions.text: The following polarizing microscopy finding is most consistent with :
questions.solution: Rhomboid crystals with weakly positive birefringence is seen in pseudogout. Whereas in gout, you will get needle shaped negatively birefringent crystals as shown below

questions.text: A lesion in the area highlighted in green is likely to produce ?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in green is the subthalamic nucleus, lesion of which produces hemiballismus.
Ballism is a violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballism). The move- ments may only affect one limb (monoballism) or, more exceptionally, both upper or lower limbs (paraballism). The movements may be so severe as to cause exhaustion, dehydration, local injury, and, in extreme cases, death. The most common cause is a partial lesion (infarct or hemorrhage) in the subthalamic nucleus, but in 30–40% of cases the lesion is found in the putamen, thalamus, or parietal cortex.
